subject: Perl v5.36 - the beginning of new era
header: A big round of applause to the entire team behind the ground breaking release of Perl v5.36. I have been following the features of the latest release very closely. I am confident it would be a solid foundation for Corinna and v7.
Have you had chance to play with Perl v5.36?
If not then please do checkout my blog post, where I shared my first hand experience playing with Perl v5.36.
Have you ever thought of contributing to your favourite language, Perl?

A little over a decade, I submitted a small patch via email. Those days, the process was not as smooth as it is today. Unfortunately I never received any acknowledgment. Ever since Perl, found the new home in GitHub, it is so easy to submit the patches. I submitted a small change to the core Perl. To my surprise, in 2 days, it got accepted and merged. It has given me confidence to submit more.
Why don't you also give it a try?
Last but not least, I would like to thank each and everyone for all the support via Patreon, I received in the last few weeks. I am overwhelmed, to be honest.
Enjoy the rest of the newsletter.

entries.author: flavio_poletti
entries.text: Structure data viewer got new home. Nice demo of Perl power.
entries.title: Curses::UI data viewer becomes dew
Do you want to get started with Perl v5.36?
entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Here is my personal journey with the latest Perl release.

entries.title: Taint in Perl
entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Dealing with taint was always a mystery to me. In this blog, I share my experience dealing with taint in Perl.

entries.title: Memory Leak in Perl
entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Memory management in Perl never an issue for many. In the blog, I tried to scratch the surface.

entries.title: Core Modules: filetest
entries.author: tom_wyant
entries.text: Tom shared the details of filetest pragma in the light of latest Perl v5.36. A very nice introduction, not to be missed.

entries.title: Entering the Charts

entries.text: Kephra presenting Charts for Perl fans. Please checkout the blog for the ground work behind it. Well done.

entries.title: Reconsidering the licensing of Perl code
entries.author: dean_hamstead
entries.text: Licensing is a tricky business. In the post, Dean helping us explain the nitty-gritty.

entries.title: Looking for a new owner for my modules
entries.author: damien_krotkine
entries.text: Damien is looking for helping hand to maintain some of his CPAN work. If you are interested and have time to dedicate then please do help him.

chapters.title: The Weekly Challenge
chapters.header: The Weekly Challenge by Mohammad Anwar will help you step out of your comfort-zone. You can even win prize money of $50 Amazon voucher by participating in the weekly challenge. We pick one winner at the end of the month from among all of the contributors during the month. The monthly prize is kindly sponsored by Peter Sergeant of PerlCareers.

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Brilliant Numbers" and "Achilles Numbers". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.
entries.title: The Weekly Challenge - 169

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Perrin Prime" and "Home Prime" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

entries.text: Great show of code reuse and CPAN, promoting the idea 'don't reinvent the wheel'. Keep it up great work.

chapters.title: Perl Tutorial
chapters.header: A section for newbies and for people who need some refreshing of their Perl knowledge. If you have questions or suggestions about the articles, let me know and I'll try to make the necessary changes. The included articles are from the Perl Maven Tutorial and are part of the Perl Maven eBook.
